Award.AwardTitle: SusChEM: Selective C-H Functionalization by Highly Tunable Metalloporphyrin Carbenoid: A Mechanistic Investigation
Award.AbstractNarration:
The Division of Chemistry supports the efforts of Professor Yong Zhang of the Stevens Institute of Technology towards selective carbon-hydrogen (C-H) functionalization using metalloporphyrin carbenoids. Metalloporphyrin carbenoids have been found to be among the most efficient and selective catalysts for C-H insertions however, mechanistic studies on these catalysts are relatively scarce and the origins of molecular reactivity and selectivity have not been well characterized. Such information is critical for the future development of these catalysts, especially since most reported C-H insertion yields are modest. Dr. Zhang's research provides systematic profiles of the origins of reactivity for key metalloporphyrin carbenes as well as reactivity and selectivity trends of various structural factors to facilitate the development of highly selective metalloporphyrin-based C-H insertion catalysts with metal centers that are earth-abundant, minimally toxic, and relatively inexpensive. Dr. Zhang's research is broadly integrated with teaching and learning. Students in his lab are actively involved in classes and outreach programs that incorporate their research results. Dr. Zhang continues his vigorous efforts to have broad participation of students from different groups at various levels, particularly including students from underrepresented groups.

Organic synthesis is of vital importance in modern society to provide drugs and materials. Selective carbon-hydrogen (C-H) functionalization represents a powerful, potentially sustainable strategy for organic synthesis. As models of broadly interesting and useful heme protein reaction intermediates, metalloporphyrin carbenoids have been found to be among the most efficient and highly selective catalysts for C-H insertions into organic molecules, even though few mechanistic studies have been done and their origin of the catalyst's reactivity and selectivity are not clear. Such information is critical for future development, especially since most C-H insertion yields using these catalysts are modest. Dr. Zhang's research provides systematic profiles of needed information such as molecular design guidelines to facilitate the development of highly selective metalloporphyrin-based C-H insertion catalysts that use earth-abundant metals (such as iron). Such insights may lead to improvements sustainable and "green" chemistry in the pharmaceutical and materials syntheses industries. Dr. Zhang's research is broadly integrated with teaching and learning. Several channels are employed by his students to broadly disseminate their research to the scientific community and general public. For example, students involved in this NSF-supported project are required to give presentations/reports in their classes, and within their department, university, K-12 institutions, museums, news media, and/or other venues, enhancing the scientific understanding of the impacts of this project.

POR.DRECONTENT:
a): Intellectual Merit

The significant novel results of this project include:

1) successful prediction of the Mössbauer spectra of iron porphyrin carbene complex; 

2) accurate predictions of the 13C NMR chemical shifts of iron porphyrin carbenes with theory-versus-experiment linear correlation coefficient R2=0.982, together with a useful discovery that 13C NMR spectroscopy may be used to probe their reactivities; 

3) successful predictions of X-ray structures of metalloporphyrin carbenes with mean absolute deviation of key bond lengths of <2%; 

4) theoretical explanation of their experimental electrophilic nature; 

5) the computational report showing that iron porphyrin carbenes are of an electronic structure unlike the assumed picture of analogous catalytic intermediates in conventional heme enzyme reactions; 

6) the theoretical explanation that the experimental binding mode of carbenes in metalloporphyrin complexes is terminal, not bridging; 

7) the mechanistic profiles of experimental iron porphyrin carbene formation pathways, with effects from various porphyrin substituents, carbene substituents, protein axial ligands, and metal centers, which provides useful information for future molecular design of facilely formed highly reactive heme-based carbene transfer catalysts;         

8) theoretical mechanistic details of C-H insertion by iron porphyrin carbenes showing an FeII-based, concerted, hydride transfer mechanism, different from the FeIV-based stepwisehydrogen atom transfer mechanism for C-H functionalization by native heme enzymes; 

9) successful predictions of a trend of broad range experimental C-H insertion yields (0-88%) of five different C-H bonds including mostly non-functionalized ones and experimental kinetic isotope effects (expt: ~1.97, calc: ~1.99); 

10) theoretical report of the origin of substrate selectivity in heme carbenoid C-H insertions from the hydride formation capability; 

11) detailed study of conformation and spin state effects on heme carbenoid C-H insertions, which reveals useful geometry, charge, and energy parameters well correlated with barriers; 

12) theoretical evidence that carbene formation is the overall rate-limiting step compared to C-H insertion, which suggests a key role of the formation of strong electrophilic heme carbene in developing heme-based C-H insertioncatalysts and biocatalysts; 

13) details (energies, geometries, charges, spin states) of how carbene substituent’s steric and electronic features, how porphyrin substituent position, number, and type, how different types of axial ligands, and how different metal centers affect heme C-H insertion reactivity and selectivity; 

b): Broader Impacts

Nine undergraduate students including six from underrepresented groups, four graduate students including two from underrepresented groups, and one postdoctoral researcher have been trained to perform research in this project. 

They have learned various kinds of quantum chemical calculations and were trained to write weekly reports and have biweekly oral presentations. They also learned to write project summaries in an ACS journal format and organize data in formatted excel files. The postdoc and graduate students also learned to help guide the more junior level students and write drafts for the PI to prepare manuscripts and grant proposals. 

Six students including four from underrepresented groups presented posters about their work in conferences. In addition, the PI also brought two selected undergraduate students from underrepresented groups to an ACS award symposium to further stimulate their interest in chemistry research and learning. Seven undergraduate students including six from underrepresented groups have taken a total of forteen semesters of research courses with the PI. In addition, the PI has taught seven undergraduate students including five from underrepresented groups how to prepare proposals for research scholarships and all of their proposals were successfully funded. Among the five undergraduate students who graduated after finishing research with the PI, four went to graduate schools and one went to medical school.

Apart from student presentations in conferences to help disseminate results from this project, the PI has delivered seventeen oral presentations and three posters in international/national/regional conferences and five university seminars (all have undergraduate students in the audience, and one of the seminars has only undergraduate students as the audience) on the finished work of this project. In addition, the senior PhD student was trained to present research results in an undergraduate course CH322 “Theoretical Chemistry”. There are several news reports in the university and social media based on the PI’s work in this period, including one interview particularly for the graduated PhD student on this project.  

 


Last Modified: 07/23/2018
Modified by: Yong Zhang
